ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminar in which we watched recorded lectures and then discussed them.

It was a mixture of live virtual lecture and discussion sessions; lecture/discussion recordings that were available after the class were super helpful in reviewing the material and/or making up for missed class times.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic understanding of the Distributed Morphology approach to morphology, and how morphology relates to syntax and phonology (at least within DM)

I learned about Distributed Morphology and its concepts. Among those, I learned about vocabulary insertion, vocabulary items, fission/fusion, allomorphy, phases and spell-out. I also learned how to effectively write a research paper.

This was a dive into a higher-level linguistics course, for sure. Learned the basics and foundations of Distributed Morphology, and tried our hands at self-driven research in related topics of our choice.

A strong foundation in the distributed morphology framework. Really refined my knowledge of word structure and linguistics in general. The paper was also a helpful introduction to writing for linguistics.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Textbook is wordy and sometimes makes simple topics confusing. Class discussion sometimes left behind those of us who hadn't taken phonology/more advanced syntax even though neither was a prerequisite. Great range of topics, and discussion posts were always fun!

Strengths: amazing professors, lot of knowledge learned, great feedback on assignments and papers, emphasis on learning, practicing and understanding concepts, outside talks offered another perspective in morphology and was helpful. Weaknesses: none, one part that I was not most fond of were the discussion posts, since they added extra stress (this is a personal qualm since I they were simple, for participation, and should not have taken too long to compose)

Strengths: This class doesn't let you fall behind or not apply material learned so far that you may have fallen behind on.

Weaknesses: This class doesn't let you fall behind or not apply material learned so far that you may have fallen behind on.

In all seriousness, though, I felt very lost at times in the first half of the semester, as concept upon concept was thrown at us with incredible speed. It was, we later learned, a planned deep crash course on morphology that would well serve us later on in the semester and give us time for research and discussion, but in the first half of the semester, I sometimes questioned my own sanity as my brain completely failed to take in all the information that we needed.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout room group exercises were often rushed because discussion took up so much of the class, but the instructors did a great job making discussion dynamic and easy to participate in through the chat and open-ended questions/topics.
I liked beginning classes with a short lecture video, answering questions, then practicing concepts. I liked the short classes three times per week too, given the remote format.

I liked the short recorded lectures that would be played synchronously with the class and then discussed/practiced as a group, and I liked the flexibility for attendance added by having two choice groups and discussion sections in back-to-back time blocks. Sometimes, however, it felt like the class was a little too much. Eventually the discussion sections turned into lectures themselves, so we were doing 3 lectures/week, all at the same quick pace of the regular sessions; the readings were very immersive, the discussion posts on Canvas forced participation (with reason, and they were fun, though sometimes daunting), the homeworks, etc.

i think maybe a more centralized experience would benefit this class -- in the beginning we weren't being notified of assignments or deadlines, it seemed as though the instructors expected us to seek out that information ourselves on a regular basis, which was a little unreasonable given the COVID-19 pandemic mindset and general stress students were under (not to mention, having to do this for multiple other classes).

However, the instructors' flexibility with and considerate actions regarding deadlines were very helpful and reassuring.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you like words, you've taken syntax and phonology, and you don't mind a little chaos (unclear assignments, often-shifting due dates, some days we just talk about whatever), take this class.

I would recommend this course to any student with a background in syntax and phonology who would like to learn more about how morphemes work and words come into being. If you don't have background in one of the two areas, the course is manageable thanks to resources that professors share, but you will get more out of the course if you have solid understanding of both areas.

If you've never taken a higher-level linguistics course or seminar, expect to be thrown into one with minimum guidance. This can be a learning experience, or a stressful one, or both. I do still recommend it to undergraduates who are interested in syntax/morphology, and would like to do more "serious" work in the current and growing field.
Yes! Prof. Wood and Sereikaite were fantastic, and they did an excellent job balancing lecture with discussion and exercises. Really interesting class if you love syntax-y things in linguistics.
